abstract: New York’s attorney general is standing up to banking interests with his complaint against JPMorgan Chase, and whether he wins support from other government quarters will be telling, an economist writes.
snippet: New York’s attorney general is standing up to banking interests with his complaint against JPMorgan Chase, and whether he wins support from other government quarters will be telling, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline.main: Money, Power and the Rule of Law
